feed.title: Your awesome title
feed.subtitle: Write an awesome description for your new site here. You can edit this line in _config.yml. It will appear in your document head meta (for Google search results) and in your feed.xml site description.

entry.title: Calculus Applications in Computer Science
entry.content:
Polar Coordinate: Hough Line Transform

Series Power Series Expansion: similar to Taylor Expansion, which is mentioned many times in Statistical Machine Learning book

Fourier Series: https://in.answers.yahoo.com/question/index?qid=20100822005038AAaIVK8&guccounter=1&guce_referrer=aHR0cHM6Ly9jbi5iaW5nLmNvbS8&guce_referrer_sig=AQAAADrxHnCdST-Gk1tW5LYC-yXTbLfFxZON5PCeu6ADQEslHSvh9zm2neE8GsA2sz5s7ehUa5KDeJ7_Cq1dQm8Xlp4hqfP6Nk0Gd3l5KhctEroDBnea9dS6zLr6am5mSmiLlDskk7ihgU7goUfskc9m9k7ZDKSAnkgOuzbvw1zzlpAx

In the above post it’s saying that JPEG compression is using fourier series, following is the original words

The changeing pattern of colours in an image can be fitted by an fourier series (in practise it is a cosine series that is used) As an infinite series could take an infinite amount of information to store it, that doesn't seem like a good thing, but the infinite series can be approximated by the first few terms.

Fourier Transform

I know better about this:

  • mfcc
  • telecom, signaling, etc. like FDMA?

http://www.dspguide.com/ch27/6.htm

http://nautil.us/blog/the-math-trick-behind-mp3s-jpegs-and-homer-simpsons-face

https://plus.maths.org/content/fourier-transforms-images

logx(y)=n => x^n=y 2^log2(n)=n

loga(b) = logc(b)/logc(a)

loga(b)=n => a^n=b

logc(b)=logc(a^n)=nlogc(a) => logc(b)/logc(a)=n=loga(b)

entry.title: PyTorch Get Version Number
entry.content:
To check the currently used pytorch version number, we can use torch.__version__

print(torch.__version__)

1.0.1
entry.summary: To check the currently used pytorch version number, we can use torch.__version__

db.killOp(1344808)

db.currentOp().inprog.filter(x => x.ns === ‘local.oplog.rs’).forEach(function(x) { print(x.client ? x.client.replace(/:.*$/,’’) : ‘-‘) })

db.currentOp(true).inprog.reduce((accumulator, connection) => { ipaddress = connection.client ? connection.client.split(“:”)[0] : “unknown”; accumulator[ipaddress] = (accumulator[ipaddress]   0) + 1; accumulator[“TOTAL_CONNECTION_COUNT”]++; return accumulator; }, { TOTAL_CONNECTION_COUNT: 0 })

entry.title: PaddleHub Emotion Detection
entry.content:
https://www.paddlepaddle.org.cn/hub?filter=en_category&value=SentimentAnalysis Lists the emotion detection models provided by PaddleHub

I only checked emotion_detection_textcnn model, it’s based on TextCNN

https://github.com/PaddlePaddle/models/tree/develop/PaddleNLP/emotion_detection

https://github.com/PaddlePaddle/models/tree/develop/PaddleNLP/sentiment_classification

It seems the content of above two links are same?

There is also a plain CNN model, according to its description, it’s different from the TextCNN model. (It’s saying TextCNN is using multiple convolutional kernel)

In summary, its provided emotion detection models include BOW, LSTM, GRU, CNN, BiLSTM, BERT, ERNIE

The BOW is using BOW as feature and FCN as network structure.
entry.summary: https://www.paddlepaddle.org.cn/hub?filter=en_category&value=SentimentAnalysis Lists the emotion detection models provided by PaddleHub

entry.title: PaddleHub Emotion Detection
entry.content:
Both Iterable and generator can be used for for .. in ..

For my archives iteration code, it’s easier to use generator(yield). Because creating generator need create class and implement __iter__ and next methods, and some variables need to change to self. style. And another reason is I used two level for loop (harder to implement for Iterator?)
entry.summary: Both Iterable and generator can be used for for .. in ..

entry.title: MongoDB query exclude specific fileds
entry.content: db.getCollection('playlists').find({AssignedUser:'18853684253'},{Videos:-1}) not working, it only return Videos field, it’s same as db.getCollection('playlists').find({AssignedUser:'18853684253'},{Videos:1})
entry.summary: db.getCollection('playlists').find({AssignedUser:'18853684253'},{Videos:-1}) not working, it only return Videos field, it’s same as db.getCollection('playlists').find({AssignedUser:'18853684253'},{Videos:1})

entry.title: Tensorflow load checkpoint
entry.content:

latest_checkpoint = tf.train.latest_checkpoint('D:/waifu_recognition_master/waifu_recognition-master/checkpoint')
print(latest_checkpoint)
g = saver.restore(sess, latest_checkpoint)

But

print(tf.all_variables())
print(tf.trainable_variables())

will display empty list
entry.summary: When I try to load meta file from checkpoint directory saver=tf.train.import_meta_graph('D:/waifu_recognition_master/waifu_recognition-master/checkpoint/model.ckpt-78681.meta')

entry.title: Tensorflow model save and load
entry.content:
##Save

saver = tf.train.Saver()
saver.save(sess,'models/tf-test4')

Load

I removed variables definition in save part

And if I kept saver = tf.train.Saver(), following error is shown

Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<input>", line 1, in <module>
  File "D:\Program Files\JetBrains\PyCharm 2019.1\helpers\pydev\_pydev_bundle\pydev_umd.py", line 197, in runfile
    pydev_imports.execfile(filename, global_vars, local_vars)  # execute the script
  File "D:\Program Files\JetBrains\PyCharm 2019.1\helpers\pydev\_pydev_imps\_pydev_execfile.py", line 18, in execfile
    exec(compile(contents+"\n", file, 'exec'), glob, loc)
  File "E:/PycharmProjects/predict_call/tf-testload.py", line 11, in <module>
    saver = tf.train.Saver()
  File "D:\Python37\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\python\training\saver.py", line 832, in __init__
    self.build()
  File "D:\Python37\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\python\training\saver.py", line 844, in build
    self._build(self._filename, build_save=True, build_restore=True)
  File "D:\Python37\lib\site-packages\tensorflow\python\training\saver.py", line 869, in _build
    raise ValueError("No variables to save")
ValueError: No variables to save

It’s because I didn’t declare any variables before saver = tf.train.Saver()

To load a model, I should use

saver=tf.train.import_meta_graph('models/tf-test4.meta')
saver.restore(sess, 'models/tf-test4')

Note that restore method accepts a filename prefix (not tf-test4.*)

Then run print(tf.trainable_variables()) to display trainable variables

The model I saved by myself can display useful data, but the model I downloaded (waifu_recognition_model) displays an empty list. But in Tensorboard Grapic section, the network structure can be displayed.

Jekyll requires blog post files to be named according to the following format:

YEAR-MONTH-DAY-title.MARKUP

Where YEAR is a four-digit number, MONTH and DAY are both two-digit numbers, and MARKUP is the file extension representing the format used in the file. After that, include the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
